'''15,000 BC in art''' involved some significant events.
== Events ==
[[Cave paintings]] were born during this time period. Historians now use these cave paintings as a guide to help them unravel [[History of the world|our civilization's history]].
== Art ==
Paintings created at [[Lascaux]].

{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox film | name = A Dirty Shame | image = a dirty shame poster.jpg | alt = | caption = Original release poster | director = [[John Waters]] | producer = {{Plainlist| * [[Christine Vachon]] * [[Ted Hope]] * [[Mark Ordesky]] * Mark Kaufman * [[Pat Moran]]}} | writer = John Waters | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Tracey Ullman]] * [[Johnny Knoxville]] * [[Selma Blair]] * [[Chris Isaak]] * [[Suzanne Shepherd]] * [[Mink Stole]]}} | music = [[George S. Clinton]] | cinematography = [[Steve Gainer]] | editing = Jeffrey Wolf | studio = {{Plainlist| * [[Killer Films]] * City Lights Pictures * This Is That}} | distributor = {{Plainlist| * [[New Line Cinema]] * [[Fine Line Features]]}} | released = {{Film date|2004|09|12|[[2004 Toronto International Film Festival|TIFF]]|2004|9|17|United States}} | runtime = 89 minutes{{cite web|title=''A DIRTY SHAME'' (18)|url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/dirty-shame-2005-2|work=[[Entertainment Film Distributors]]|publisher=[[British Board of Film Classification]]|date=September 15, 2004|accessdate=October 25, 2013}} | country = United States | language = English | gross = $1.9 million }} '''''A Dirty Shame''''' is a 2004 American [[Satire|satirical]] [[sex comedy]] film written and directed by [[John Waters]] and starring [[Tracey Ullman]], [[Johnny Knoxville]], [[Selma Blair]], [[Chris Isaak]], [[Suzanne Shepherd]], and [[Mink Stole]]. {{As of|2018}}, this is Waters' most recent directorial effort. He cites the film's poor box office returns as keeping his future projects from being green-lit, though he has indicated that he would be willing to make another film if sufficient funding were secured.{{cite web | url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2013/nov/03/interview-john-waters-pink-flamingos-liverpool | title=John Waters: 'Doing the show is an effective anti-Alzheimer's exercise' | work=[[The Guardian]] | publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]] | date=November 2, 2013 | accessdate=January 28, 2015}} ==Plot== The people of [[Harford Road]] are firmly divided into two camps: neuters, the [[puritan]]ical residents who despise anything even remotely carnal; and the perverts, a group of [[Sexual addiction|sex addicts]] whose unique [[Sexual fetishism|fetish]]es have all been brought to the fore by accidental [[concussion]]s. Repressed Sylvia Stickles finds herself firmly entrenched in the former camp. One day, after leaving her [[Promiscuity|promiscuous]] daughter Caprice (nicknamed Ursula Udders because of gargantuan breasts and a penchant for [[indecent exposure]] while dancing at a local dive bar) locked up over the garage, under [[house arrest]] "for her own good", Sylvia is smacked on the head by a passing car and meets Ray-Ray Perkins, a local mechanic and self-styled "sex saint" who opens her mind to a whole new world of sensual pleasure, as he and his followers search for the ultimate sex act. Eventually, through a series of bizarre head knockings, everyone in the Harford Road area of Baltimore becomes a sex addict, as Ray-Ray shoots [[semen]] out of his head, and becomes the messiah of "Let's Go Sexin'!". ==Cast== {{div col}} * [[Tracey Ullman]] as Sylvia Stickles * [[Johnny Knoxville]] as Ray-Ray Perkins * [[Selma Blair]] as Caprice Stickles/"Ursula Udders" * [[Chris Isaak]] as Vaughn Stickles * [[Suzanne Shepherd]] as Big Ethel * [[Mink Stole]] as Marge * [[Patricia Hearst]] as Paige * [[Jackie Hoffman]] as Dora * [[Wes Johnson]] as Fat Fuck Frank * [[Paul DeBoy]] as Wendell Doggett * [[Gaelan Connell|Gaelan Alexander Connell]] as Horny kid * [[Channing Wilroy]] as Male motorist * Rosemary Knower as Female motorist * Alan J. Wendl as Officer Alvin * [[James Ransone]] as Dingy Dave * David A. Dunham as Mama Bear * Dave Moretti as Papa Bear * Jeffrey Auerbach as Baby Bear * Jewel Orem as Officer Loose Linda * Jonas Grey as Warren the mailman * David DeBoy as Dr. Arlington * Doug Roberts as Driving neuter husband * [[Mary Vivian Pearce]] as Nonjudgmental ex-sex addict * [[Jean Hill (actress)|Jean Hill]] as Woman at fire escape * Ty Ford as the taxi cab driver * Bob Adams as Bus passenger * [[George Figgs]] (''uncredited'') as Neuter * [[Ricki Lake]] (''[[Cameo appearance|cameo]]'') as herself * [[David Hasselhoff]] (''cameo'') as himself {{div col end}} ==Production== [[John Waters]] decided to make the film after discovering several sexual slang terms and branches existed on the internet, explaining the groups and terminology found in the film.DVD Features According to Waters, when he asked the [[Motion Picture Association of America|MPAA]] what he would need to cut in order for them to give his film an [[Motion Picture Association of America film rating system|R rating]], they replied that "after a while, we just stopped taking notes", and if everything they objected to was cut, only ten minutes could be distributed.{{Cite video | people = John Waters | url = https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0493459/|title=This Film Is Not Yet Rated | medium = Movie | publisher = Independent Film Channel (IFC) | date = 2006 }} They decided to simply release it with an [[NC-17]] rating. It was shot entirely on-location in [[Baltimore]] on [[Maryland Route 147|Harford Road]] which is prominently featured in the film. In a featurette that accompanied the film's DVD release, veteran stage actress Suzanne Shepherd recalled that when she was cast as Big Ethel, she was completely unfamiliar with Waters' work, and she had no idea what to expect when she showed up for the first script review. Horrified by what she was reading, she became so distraught that she began to cry. She tried to quit the project, but Waters and her cast mates managed to persuade her to stay."All the Dirt on ''A Dirty Shame,''" New Line Home Video, 2005. ==Reception== ''A Dirty Shame'' received a mixed response from critics; some have lauded its unashamed vulgarity, while others have lampooned it for the same reason. On [[review aggregator]] website [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film holds an approval rating of 53% based on 117 reviews, and an [[average rating]] of 5.5/10.{{cite web |url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/dirty_shame |title=A Dirty Shame (2004) |work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |publisher=[[Fandango (company)|Fandango Media]] |accessdate=March 13, 2018}} On [[Metacritic]], the film has a weighted average score of 56 out of 100, based on 34 critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews".{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/a-dirty-shame |title=A Dirty Shame Reviews |work=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=March 13, 2018}} One of the more positive reviews came from Kevin Thomas of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', who wrote:
"A gross-out pioneer, Waters has always had more on his mind than delirious, sex-crazed silliness. By allowing people to speak freely about their sexual urges and practices with a bluntness that is jaw-droppingly hilarious, Waters has drawn deeply upon comedy's liberating power. The more the sex addicts talk about their hang-ups the more comically harmless they seem, and thus it's all the more absurd for the puritanical to try to punish them for their various pursuits of pleasure. Waters has always harnessed poor taste to lampoon attempts to limit freedom of expression. This raucously gritty and high-spirited film could scarcely be bluer in terms of the language, but from Waters it comes as a gust of fresh air."{{cite web |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2004/sep/24/entertainment/et-Dirty24 |title=John Waters returns to his 'Dirty' roots |first=Kevin |last=Thomas |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=September 24, 2004 |accessdate=March 13, 2018}}
Also enthusiastic was [[Peter Travers]] of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'':
"''A Dirty Shame'' is Waters unleashed, and wicked, kinky fun for anyone except the twits who rated it NC-17...You may even shed a tear when Sylvia bonds with her daughter by confessing, "I'm a cunnilingus bottom." OK, the jokes are hit-and-miss and the plot is nonexistent, but the Waters spirit stays consistently and sweetly twisted. When the cast takes to the streets singing, "Let's go sexin'," you want to cheer them on."{{cite web |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/reviews/a-dirty-shame-20040914 |title=A Dirty Shame |first=Peter |last=Travers |work=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=September 14, 2004 |accessdate=March 13, 2018}}
On the other end of the spectrum was [[Roger Ebert]], who gave the film one star out of a possible four:
"There is in show biz something known as "a bad laugh." That's the laugh you don't want to get, because it indicates not amusement but incredulity, nervousness or disapproval. John Waters' ''A Dirty Shame'' is the only comedy I can think of that gets more bad laughs than good ones...We go to a Waters film expecting bad taste, but we also expect to laugh, and ''A Dirty Shame'' is monotonous, repetitive and sometimes wildly wrong in what it hopes is funny."{{cite web |url=https://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/a-dirty-shame-2004 |title=A Dirty Shame |first=Roger |last=Ebert |authorlink=Roger Ebert |work=RogerEbert.com |publisher=Ebert Digital LLC |date=September 24, 2004 |accessdate=March 13, 2018}}
===Box office=== ''A Dirty Shame'' opened on September 17, 2004 on one Baltimore screen to $29,384. The next weekend, it expanded to 133 venues, where it grossed $448,914 ($3,375 per screen). It ended its North American run with $1,339,668 (as of November 7, 2004).{{Cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=weekly&id=dirtyshame.htm|title=Box Office Mojo -- Weekly Box Office Results -- A Dirty Shame|publisher=IMDb.com, Inc.| accessdate = July 12, 2010}} Overseas, the film earned an additional $574,498 (as of July 14, 2005), making its global box office total come to $1,914,166. ==Home media== {{Refimprove section|date = September 2018}} There is both a full uncensored version and an edited, R-rated cut sold through [[Blockbuster Inc.|Blockbuster]], [[Wal-Mart]], and [[Best Buy]] as well as [[Target Corporation|Target]] dubbed "''The Neuter Version''". The R-rated version is heavily censored and removes most of the profanities including altered dialogue such as "sex toy". Additionally, a scene in which two characters stand naked in their doorway is replaced by one in which the characters are clothed. In an interview, Waters stated that this version is "essentially for brainless people and 'really weird collectors'."See the documentary film, ''[[This Film Is Not Yet Rated]]'', in which Waters discusses many aspects of the difficulties he had with the MPAA rating system. [[Netflix]] proclaims to stream the NC-17 version of the film, but for a time, it was actually the censored version. It has since replaced it with the uncensored cut. A heavily censored version aired on [[Logo (TV channel)|LOGO]], a cable channel for gay interest. Despite several internet sites and even the spine of the DVD stating that it is "The Neuter Version", the Australian release of the film is the NC-17 version{{cite web|url=http://www.ezydvd.com.au/DVD/dirty-shame-a/dp/799492/799492|title=Buy Dirty Shame, A on DVD-Video from EzyDVD.com.au|publisher=[[EzyDVD]]|accessdate=April 17, 2014}} with all profanity and nudity intact. It is rated [[Australian Classification Board|R18+]] for "sexual references and adult themes". ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{wikiquote}} * {{IMDb title|0365125}} * {{mojo title|dirtyshame}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|dirty_shame}} * {{metacritic film|a-dirty-shame}} {{John Waters}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dirty Shame, A}} [[Category:2004 films]] [[Category:2000s comedy films]] [[Category:2000s LGBT-related films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American LGBT-related films]] [[Category:American sex comedy films]] [[Category:Bisexuality-related films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films about sex addiction]] [[Category:Films set in Baltimore]] [[Category:Films set in Maryland]] [[Category:Films shot in Baltimore]] [[Category:Films shot in Maryland]] [[Category:Lesbian-related films]] [[Category:LGBT-related comedy films]] [[Category:Sexual addiction in fiction]] [[Category:Films directed by John Waters]] [[Category:Films produced by Christine Vachon]] [[Category:Killer Films films]]

revision.text:
{{Antisemitism}} '''Antisemitica''' designates, in the fields of [[book collecting]], and [[rare book]] dealing, the collection and distribution of books, pamphlets, serials, posters, and other printed literature, of an [[antisemitic]] nature. It is to be noted that antisemitica does not, generally, designate antisemitic activity, or antisemites themselves. In the [[United States]], the [[freedom of the press]] does not limit the publication or distribution of antisemitic literature, and there are scholarly and historical interests in such material.
== See also == *[[Bibliophilia]]
== External links == *[http://www.danwymanbooks.com/fearthejew.htm A catalog of antisemitica] at Dan Wyman Books *[http://digifindingaids.cjh.org/?pID=109172 Antisemitic Literature Collection] held at the [[American Jewish Historical Society]], New York, NY
[[Category:Antisemitic publications]] [[Category:Books by type]] [[Category:Book collecting]]
{{lit-stub}}

{{COI|date=May 2018}}{{Infobox person | name = Antoñita Singla | image = La Singla 2.JPG | alt = Antoñita Singla | birth_name = Antonia Singla-Contreras | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1948}} | birth_place = Barcelona, Spain | residence = Catalonia, Spain | nationality = Spanish | other_names = La Singla, Antoñita la Singla | years_active = 1960 - 1988 | notable_works = Los Tarantos | known_for = Flamenco dancer }}
'''Antoñita Singla''' (born 1948),<ref name=":2" /> is a [[Spaniards|Spanish]] [[flamenco]] dancer and actress. She often went by the stage name '''Antoñita La Singla''' or simply "La Singla" but sometimes its written as '''Antonia Singla'''.
== Biography == ===Early life=== She was born as '''Antonia Singla Contreras''' in 1948 in the neighborhood [[Somorrostro de la Barceloneta]], in Barcelona.<ref name=":4" />
A few days after her birth she was in pain so her mother took her to many hospitals in order to see different doctors. Despite the examinations, no accurate medical diagnosis was found. It was thought that the pain was caused by severe [[meningitis]], however, the little girl was left [[deaf]] as a result of the pain she suffered during her first months.<ref name=":4">{{cita web |url= https://elartedevivirelflamenco.com/bailaores206.html|title= ANTOÑITA LA SINGLA|year=2003|access-date= 6 May 2018|editor= El Arte de Vivir el Flamenco|language= spanish}}</ref> In 1968, she made a partial recovery from her medical condition.<ref name=":2" />
While she was growing up, La Singla learned to dance rumba, fandango, bulerías and flamenco with considerable skill.<ref name=":6">{{cita web |url= http://maverickmedicinebabe.blogspot.com.es/2012/10/la-singla-antonitas-miraculous-story.html|title= La Singla Antonita's miraculous story|access-date= 6 May 2018|last= Medicine Babe|first= Maverick|date= 30 October 2012|cita=}} </ref> Singla began to dance by watching her mother clapping, absorbing the rhythm and turning it into a really remarkable dance full of emotions. It is said that she did not speak fluently until the age of 16.<ref name=":6" />
===Artistic career=== [[File:La Singla 1.JPG|thumb|right|La Singla dancing]] Singla began her career at the early age of 12, dancing in some taverns in Barcelona. Her mastery of dance took her to the top, arriving to perform at the [[Olympia (Paris)|Olympia]] in Paris, in Berlin and in Stuttgart, among other cities.{{Citation needed|date=May 2018}} She was known for wearing pants when performing dramatic dancing.<ref name=":1" /> In 1960, she launched her artistic career to the top by participating in the group project [[Festival Flamenco Gitano]]<ref name=":8">{{cita web |url=https://elpais.com/cultura/2015/12/23/babelia/1450888812_211989.html |title= El primer Festival Flamenco Gitano|access-date= 6 May 2018|last= Lobatón|first= Fermín|date= 7 January 2016 |language= ES|cita=}}</ref> in which personalities such as [[Paco de Lucía]], [[Camarón de la Isla]], and [[El Faraón]], among others, participated.{{Citation needed|date=May 2018}} This 1965 event was the brainchild of German organizers of Blues and Gospel festivals, who decided to invest in flamenco, later participating in numerous television programs. In addition, the Festival Flamenco Gitano toured Europe and the American continent. The first performance took place in the German capital, Berlin. It is worth noting the fact that La Singla was more famous internationally than in Spain.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=Flamenco|last=Schreiner|first=Claus|last2=Pauly|first2=Reinhard G.|last3=Claus|first3=Madeleine|publisher=Hal Leonard Corporation|year=1990|isbn=1574670131|location=|pages=117}}</ref>
In 1963, she performed as an actress and dancer in the film [[Los Tarantos]], directed by [[Francisco Rovira Beleta|Francisco Rovira-Beleta]]. The film is based on a play by Alfredo Mañas and tells the story of the fierce confrontation between two gypsy families in Barcelona: "Los Tarantos" and "Los Zorongos". At a wedding, Rafael, Taranto, meets Juana, La Zoronga. The two young people, wrapped by the magic of the party, swear eternal love with a pact of blood, and after a night of love, they discover with desperation that they belong to the two rival families. Rafael's mother, seduced by the spell of Juana's dance, overcomes the ancestral hatred, but Juana's father refuses to accept the union. Antoñita La Singla participated in the film as 'Sole', one of the dancers of the clan, along with [[Sara Lezana]], Daniel Martín, Antonio Gades, Antonio Prieto, José Manuel Martín, Margarita Lozano, [[Juan Manuel Soriano]].{{Citation needed|date=May 2018}} In addition, thanks to the filming of the movie La Singla was able to meet [[Carmen Amaya]],<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=farZoyKozikC&source|title=Gypsies and Flamenco: The Emergence of the Art of Flamenco in Andalusia|last=Leblon|first=Bernard|publisher=Univ of Hertfordshire Press|year=2003|isbn=1902806050|location=Great Britain|pages=}}</ref> with whom she was compared too. The film, Los Tarantos was nominated for an [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]] in 1964 for "Best Foreign Language Film". At present, the film serves as a documentary of the now defunct Somorrostro district.
Another important milestone in the career of Antoñita Singla was her performance in the flamenco club Los Califas, a 1964 flamenco club whose [[tablao]] flamenco was inaugurated on October 15, 1965.{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} The club owners heard about her through the artistic manager Antonio Fernández, who assured them that Singla had the blessing of the great [[Salvador Dalí]] and his wife [[Gala Dalí|Gala]] as well as the support of [[Vicente Escudero]]. A few days later she traveled to Madrid ready to debut in "Los Califas".<ref name=":5">{{cita web |url=http://elblogdepacobanegas.es/index.php/mi-archivo/antonita-la-singla/262-antonita-la-singla-3|title= ANTOÑITA LA SINGLA|access-date=6 May 2018|last= Banegas|first= Paco|date=4 April 2018|language=ES|cita=}} </ref> Obviously, it was not easy to accompany "La Singla", not having the hearing and the speech needed, however she maintained the performance in its entirety. She danced by pure instinct, she did not hear the guitar or the flamenco singer. It was commented that she was going her own way, she was totally independent, and it was the others who had to follow her to give the performance the feeling of unity. This unexpected situation created such a high expectation that the flamenco club ‘’Los Califas’’ was entirely filled with professionals from the flamenco dance community and Singla exceeded all expectations.<ref name=":5" />
== Legacy == Today, Singla lives in [[Santa Coloma de Gramenet]],<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=http://www.elperiodico.cat/ca/barcelona/20170317/la-singla-del-somorrostro-a-lolympia-5906621|title=Del Somorrostro a l'Olympia|last=Merino|first=Olga|date=17 March 2017|access-date=6 May 2018|language=ES}}</ref> in Catalonia, Spain far from the tablaos.
On April 15, 2017, one of the brothers of the artist, Juan José Singla Contreras, and his partner, Santiago Parra, opened a flamenco tablao<ref name=":7">{{cita web |url= https://cronicaglobal.elespanol.com/vida/tablao-flamenco-barcelona-singla_69263_102.html|title= El nuevo templo del flamenco en la Cataluña del 'procés'|access-date= |last= Jorro|first= Ignasi|date= 8 March 2017|language= ES|cita=}}</ref> in Barcelona with the name of La Singla to pay tribute. The location of La Singla is located in front of [[La Monumental]] bullring, and it is the first flamenco establishment that opened in the city in 30 years.<ref name=":3" />
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
== External links == * Video: [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4ZFLEoOk8LA 1960s Antonita Singla dancing at Festival Flamenco Gitano] *Video: [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RCm0mJYBV1k Antoñita while dancing in 1965 ] *Video: [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mCUKIbZ-Yo0 Fragment of ''Los Tarantos''] *Video: [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lQ1nCSrOxwQ&feature=youtu.be La Singla in the Feria]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Singla, Antoñita}} [[Category:1948 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Flamenco dancers]] [[Category:Deaf artists]] [[Category:Spanish female dancers]] [[Category:Artists with disabilities]] [[Category:People from Barcelona]]

revision.text:
'''Arab cinema''' or '''Arabic cinema''', refers to the cinema of the [[Arab world]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shafik|first1=Viola|title=Arab cinema : history and cultural identity|date=2007|publisher=The American University in Cairo Press|location=Cairo, Egypt|isbn=9774160657|edition=New rev.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Learning About Arab Film and Cinema|url=http://www.arabfilmfestival.org/learning-about-arab-film-and-cinema/|website=Arab Film Festival|date=29 July 2016}}</ref> [[File:T E Lawrence and the Arab Revolt 1916 - 1918 Q58774.jpg|thumb|''T E Lawrence and the Arab Revolt 1916-1918'', a scene (probably a set piece for cinema representation), showing a crowd of soldiers, both local and Indian, at [[Wejh]], a port on the [[Red Sea]] coast north of [[Yenbo]], 1913 (First World War, Pre-1914)]]
==Overview== Arabic cinema is dominated by [[Cinema of Egypt|Egyptian movies]]. Three quarters of all Arab movies are produced in Egypt.
There is increased interest in films originating in the Arab world. For example, films from [[Algeria]], [[Lebanon]], [[Morocco]], the [[State of Palestine|Palestine]], [[Syria]] and [[Tunisia]] are making wider and more frequent rounds than ever before in local film festivals and repertoire theaters.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m2501/is_1-2_27/ai_n15694703|title=FindArticles.com {{!}} CBSi|website=findarticles.com|access-date=2018-02-05}}</ref>
==Festivals== There are numerous film festivals that have historically been and are held in various parts of the Arab world to both honor and showcase films from the Arab regions, as well as international standouts.
Since 1976, [[Cairo]] has held the annual [[Cairo International Film Festival]], which has been accredited by the [[International Federation of Film Producers Associations]].<ref>[http://www.ukhotmovies.com/film-festivals/cairo-film-festival/information.html Cairo Film Festival information] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111208183113/http://www.ukhotmovies.com/film-festivals/cairo-film-festival/information.html |date=2011-12-08 }}.</ref> There is also another festival held in [[Alexandria]]. Of the more than 4,000 short- and feature-length films made in Arabic-speaking countries since 1908, more than three-quarters were Egyptian.
In 1987, the inaugural Mogadishu Pan-African and Arab Film Symposium (Mogpaafis) was held, bringing together an array of prominent filmmakers and movie experts from across the globe, including other parts of Northeast Africa and the Arab world, as well as [[Asia]] and [[Europe]]. Held annually in [[Mogadishu]], the capital of [[Somalia]], the film festival was organized by the [[Somali Film Agency]], the nation's film regulatory body.<ref name="CEC">Commission of the European Communities, ''The Courier'', Issue 101, (Commission of the European Communities: 1987), p.97</ref>
The [[International Film Festival of Marrakech]] (FIFM) is an international [[film festival]] held annually in [[Marrakech]], [[Morocco]]. Since its inaugural year in 2000, the FIFM has been one of the biggest events devoted to [[Cinema of Morocco|Moroccan cinema]]. It is also the site of the [[principal photography]] of many international productions. The festival's jury gathers international writers, actors and personalities, and endeavors to reward the best Moroccan and foreign [[Feature film|feature]] and [[short film]]s. The FIFM is chaired by [[Prince Moulay Rachid of Morocco]].
[[File:Dubai-Filmfestival-2010.jpg|thumb|20m wide [[Inflatable movie screen|inflatable projection screen]] at the 2010 [[Dubai International Film Festival]].]] The [[Dubai International Film Festival]] (DIFF) is an international [[film festival]] based in [[Dubai]], [[United Arab Emirates]]. Launched in 2004, it aims to foster the growth of filmmaking in the Arab world.<ref name="DIFFa">{{cite web|url=http://www.dubaifilmfest.com/index.php/en/about/intro/|title=Dubai International Film Festival|work=Dubai International Film Festival|access-date=2011-05-20|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110525111646/http://www.dubaifilmfest.com/index.php/en/about/intro|archive-date=2011-05-25|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> The DIFF is held under the honorary Chairmanship of [[Ahmed bin Saeed Al Maktoum]]. It is a not-for-profit cultural event, presented and organised by the [[Dubai Internet City|Dubai Technology, Electronic Commerce and Media Free Zone Authority]].
The DIFF presents cinematic excellence from around the world and offers a high-profile platform for aspiring home-grown talent. The Muhr Award for Excellence in Arab Cinema was launched in 2006, with the aim of recognizing Arab filmmakers both regionally and internationally. In 2008, the Muhr Awards for Excellence were expanded to include two separate competitions, the Arab Muhr Award, and the AsiaAfrica Muhr Award. It also introduced a new program segment dedicated exclusively to Animation.
The [[Abu Dhabi Film Festival]] (ADFF) is another key international film festival in the larger Arab region. Created in 2007, the ceremony is held annually in October in [[Abu Dhabi]], UAE by the [[Abu Dhabi Authority for Culture and Heritage]] (ADACH), under the patronage of Sheikh Sultan Bin Tahnoon Al Nahyan, Chairman of the ADACH. The ADFF aims to encourage and foster the growth of filmmaking in the [[Arab world]] by showcasing movies from the region alongside standout productions from prominent international filmmakers.<ref name="Adff">{{cite web|url=http://www.abudhabifilmfestival.ae/en/about|title=About - Sanad Abu Dhabi Film Fund|work=Abu Dhabi Film Festival}}</ref> The first festival debuted with 152 movies and 186 screenings shown in five Abu Dhabi venues. A total of 76 feature films and 34 short films from over 35 countries competed for the Black Pearl Awards.
The [[Doha Tribeca Film Festival]] (DTFF) is an annual five-day [[film festival]] founded in 2009 to promote [[Arab]] and international film, and to develop a sustainable [[film industry]] in [[Qatar]].<ref>[http://www.gulf-times.com/site/topics/article.asp?cu_no=2&item_no=412351&version=1&template_id=36&parent_id=16 Article in Gulf Times January 2011] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110128162702/http://www.gulf-times.com/site/topics/article.asp?cu_no=2&item_no=412351&version=1&template_id=36&parent_id=16 |date=2011-01-28 }}</ref> The Festival is one of Qatar's largest entertainment events attracting over 50,000 guests in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dohafilminstitute.com/filmfestival/festival|title=About — Ajyal Youth Film Festival - Doha Film Institute|publisher=}}</ref>
DTFF is the annual film festival of the [[Doha Film Institute]], an organisation founded by [[Al-Mayassa bint Hamad bin Khalifa Al-Thani|H.E. Sheikha Al Mayassa bint Hamad bin Khalifa Al-Thani]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tradearabia.com/news/MEDIA_179834.html|title=Qatar launches new film institute|publisher=}}</ref> which implements, consolidates and oversees film initiatives in Qatar.
The 3rd annual DTFF is scheduled to take place from October 25–29, 2011 at Katara Cultural Village, [[Doha]]. Approximately 40 films will screen at the festival, within various themed sections, showcasing World and Middle Eastern Cinema.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/5/32/18816/Arts--Culture/Film/El-Shouq-to-participate-in-Doha-Tribeca-Film-Festi.aspx|title=El Shouq to participate in Doha Tribeca Film Festival|publisher=}}</ref>
==Support initiatives== In conjunction with the European Audiovisual Entrepreneurs (EAVE) professional training, networking and project development organization, the Dubai International Film Festival in 2010 also began offering to filmmakers the Interchange group of development and co-production workshops earmarked for directors, screenwriters and producers from the larger Arab region.<ref name="DIFF">{{cite web|url=http://www.dubaifilmfest.com/index.php/en/dubai_film_market/film-forum/interchange/|title=Dubai International Film Festival|work=Dubai International Film Festival}}</ref>
In 2011, the Abu Dhabi Film Festival launched the SANAD development and post-production fund for cineastes from the Arab world. With the goal of encouraging independent and [[Auteur theory|auteur]]-based cinema, eligible filmmakers now have access to financial grants, screenwriting and pitch workshops, and personal meetings with industry mentors and experts.<ref name="Afacadff">{{cite web|url=http://www.abudhabifilmfestival.ae/sites/default/files/press_releases/PR_AFACSANADLab_En.pdf |format=PDF |title=AFAC and Abu Dhabi Film Festival Partner to Support Arab Documentaries Through the SANAD FilmLab |website=abudhabifilmfestival.ae |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110903044458/http://www.abudhabifilmfestival.ae/sites/default/files/press_releases/PR_AFACSANADLab_En.pdf |archivedate=2011-09-03 |df= }}</ref>
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== *Josef Gugler (ed.) ''Film in the Middle East and North Africa: Creative Dissidence'', University of Texas Press and American University in Cairo Press, 2011, {{ISBN|978-0-292-72327-6}}, {{ISBN|978-9-774-16424-8}} *Josef Gugler (ed.) ''Ten Arab Filmmakers: Political Dissent and Social Critique'', Indiana University Press, 2015, {{ISBN|978-0-253-01652-2}} *Rebecca Hillauer: ''Encyclopedia of Arab Women Filmmakers'', American University in Cairo Press, 2005, {{ISBN|978-9-774-24943-3}} *Laura U. Marks: ''Hanan al-Cinema: Affections for the Moving Image'', MIT Press 2015, {{ISBN|978-0262029308}} *[[Viola Shafik]]: ''Arab Cinema: History and Cultural Identity'', American University in Cairo Press, revised and updated 2015, {{ISBN|978-9-774-16690-7}}
==External links== * [http://www.zenithfoundation.com/film-festival/ Zenith Arab Film Festival (UK)] * [http://www.malloftheemirates.com/entertainment/vox-cinemas Vox Cinemas UAE] * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/3591528.stm New Arab cinema tells intimate stories] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100420053556/http://www.arabfilms.org/ Arab films] * [http://arabfilmfestival.com.au Arab film festival (Australia)]

page.title: Bath School of Art and Design

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9)
revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox university | name = Bath School of Art and Design | established = 1852 | former_names = Bath School of Art | parent = [[Bath Spa University]] | city = [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]], [[Somerset]] | country = [[United Kingdom]] | coor = {{Coord|51.39377|N|2.371239|W|region:GB_type:edu|format=dms|display=title,inline}} | website = {{URL|http://artdesign.bathspa.ac.uk/}} }} '''Bath School of Art and Design''' is an [[art college]] in [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]], England. It forms part of the [[Bath Spa University]] whose main campus is located a few miles from the City at [[Newton Park]], between Newton St Loe and [[Corston, Somerset|Corston]], in North Somerset, just outside the city of Bath. The present Executive Dean is Professor Anita Taylor.
==History== The school was founded as Bath School of Art in 1852 following [[The Great Exhibition]] of 1851.<ref name="saatchi">{{cite web | url=http://www.saatchi-gallery.co.uk/artcolleges/InfoAll/introduction/ac_id/248 | title=Introduction – Bath Spa University | publisher=The Saatchi Gallery | accessdate=12 December 2010}}</ref> The Bath Directory for 1856 shows its location at Weymouth House (roughly the rear of the present Marks and Spencers store) and its Master as Anthony Carey Stannus, an Irish painter noted for marine scenes and who later helped establish a society which evolved into the [[Royal Ulster Academy]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newulsterbiography.co.uk/index.php/home/viewPerson/1561 |title=Featured person- Anthony Carey Stannus (1830–1919) Artist |publisher=Ulster History Circle-Dictionary of Ulster Biography|accessdate=17 November 2010}}</ref> By the 1858 edition he had been succeeded by John J. Drummond, who by 1860 had set up his own Mr Drummond's School of Art at 3 Bladud Buildings, and later (1862) at 5 Princes Buildings almost opposite.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.historicaldirectories.org/hd/findbyperiod.asp|title=Post office Bath Directory|date=1864 |work=Page 310 Princes Buildings |publisher=Historical Directories |accessdate=15 November 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101113155714/http://www.historicaldirectories.org/hd/findbyperiod.asp| archivedate= 13 November 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
The original School moved to Hetling House, Westgate Buildings, an ancient building which [[George Newenham Wright]] in his ''Historic Guide to Bath'' (1864) says had been garrisoned for the Royalists in the [[English Civil War|Civil War]], adding that "the School of Design now occupies the principal and older part".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.historicaldirectories.org/hd/findbyperiod.asp|title=Post office Bath Directory|date=1864 |work=Page 831 Hetling Court School of Art |publisher=Historical Directories |accessdate=15 November 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101113155714/http://www.historicaldirectories.org/hd/findbyperiod.asp| archivedate= 13 November 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The Master for a few years was John Hill, who later continued as a private tutor and artist at his home in [[Combe Down]] until about 1884. The School's syllabus was "in connection with Marlborough House", which meant the Government School of Design and Practical Art.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.historicaldirectories.org/hd/findbyperiod.asp|title=Post office Bath Directory|date=1864 |work=Page 493 Bath School of Art Master John Hill|publisher=Historical Directories |accessdate=15 November 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101113155714/http://www.historicaldirectories.org/hd/findbyperiod.asp| archivedate= 13 November 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> [[Image:Walcot School and the Star Inn, Vineyards, Bath - geograph.org.uk - 179560.jpg|thumb|right|The Star Inn and Walcot School]]
By 1866 the School was at 33 [[The Paragon, Bath|Paragon]], opposite The Star Inn, and the Master was Robert Campbell Puckett, PhD, whose 1871 work "Sciography, or radial projection of shadows" was published by Chapman & Hall of London. The tuition fee was one guinea per quarter according to the school's prospectus published as a one-page advertisement in the annual Directories. Courses were "in connection with the Science and Art Department, South Kensington". A branch was opened at The Corridor for evening classes. Later Head Masters were [[William Harbutt]] (1874), the inventor of [[Plasticine]], John Charles Swallow (1878), and Charles M. Hodges (1880). By 1884 William Harbutt was teaching at The Paragon Art Studio, 15 Bladud Buildings.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.historicaldirectories.org/hd/findbyperiod.asp|title=Post office Bath Directory|date=1884 |work=Page 125 Harbutt William-artist and teacher-The Paragon Art Studio|publisher=Historical Directories |accessdate=15 November 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101113155714/http://www.historicaldirectories.org/hd/findbyperiod.asp| archivedate= 13 November 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
By 1894 the School had come under the umbrella of the [[Bath Technical School]]s<ref>Bath Central Library{{cite book|title=Kelly's Directory|year=1897|pages=45}}</ref> and in April 1896 these occupied the new north extension of the Guildhall, including the retitled School of Art, Art Crafts and Design.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bathintime.co.uk/image.php?id=421071&idx=16&fromsearch=true|title=Plan for sites adjoining the Guildhall (Technical Schools) 14 March 1891|work=Central Library Collection|publisher=Bath in Time|accessdate=17 November 2010}}</ref> The new Head Art Master was Frank Griffin ARCA who had won bronze and silver medals, replaced by Nathaniel Heard ARCA by 1906. By 1912 the Master was Henry Wilkinson ARCA who had been taught by Ruskin and whose son (also Henry) became a well-known engraver. Successors were D.S. (probably Douglas) Andrews ARCA (1920) and Arthur Payne ARCA (1922).
The Technical Schools evolved into the Municipal [[Bath Technical College]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bathintime.co.uk/image.php?id=421065&idx=7&fromsearch=true|title=Plan of Technical Schools (first floor) 1932|work=Central Library Collection|publisher=Bath in Time|accessdate=17 November 2010}}</ref> which moved to the building in Beau Street vacated by the Royal United Hospital when it moved to Combe Park.<ref>A potted History of the RUH [http://www.ruh.nhs.uk/about/history.asp?menu_id=1] Retrieved 17 November 2010</ref><ref>Medical Heritage {{cite web |url=http://www.medicalheritage.co.uk/Bath/RUH.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-11-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716182426/http://www.medicalheritage.co.uk/Bath/RUH.htm |archivedate=16 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Retrieved 17 November 2010</ref> The process was overseen by the new head art master, the artist Paul Fripp (1934–37).<ref>{{cite web | url=http://web.ukonline.co.uk/bean95/ft/frippuk/links/rod/paul-fripp-broch.htm | title=Paul Fripp | publisher=The Fripp & Pocock families | accessdate=12 December 2010 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080821191535/http://web.ukonline.co.uk/bean95/ft/frippuk/links/rod/paul-fripp-broch.htm | archive-date=21 August 2008 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }}</ref> Then came the important appointment of the long serving [[Clifford Ellis]] (1937–1972).<ref name="celebration">{{cite web | url=http://www.baacorsham.co.uk/A_Celebration_of_Bath%20Academy_of_Art.pdf | title=A celebration of Bath Academy of Art | last=Pope | first=Derek | publisher=Bath Academy of Art | accessdate=12 December 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110106000626/http://www.baacorsham.co.uk/A_Celebration_of_Bath%20Academy_of_Art.pdf| archivedate= 6 January 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The School of Art moved to 7 and 8 Green Park early in [[World War II]], when the Beau Street building was taken over by the Admiralty. This new home was totally destroyed by bombs in April 1942, and temporary refuge was found at the home of the artist [[Walter Sickert]] at [[Bathampton]]. Sickert had been a part-time teacher at the School but had died in January 1942.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/story.asp?storycode=412031 | title=Odds and quads | publisher=Times Higher Education | accessdate=12 December 2010}}</ref> Clifford Ellis is said to have cut the lettering on Sickert's headstone. [[File:CorshamCourtFront.jpg|thumb|[[Corsham Court]]]] In November 1942 the School began its association with 99 Sydney Place. A note in the local history section of Bath Central Library<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/nra/onlinelists/GB0256%20MSS.pdf|title=Bath Central Library|work=National archives NRA 25737|publisher=nationalarchives.gov.uk|accessdate=22 November 2010}}</ref> records the opening of the new premises by Sir Kenneth Clark, then Director of the [[National Gallery]] and Surveyor of the King's Pictures.<ref name="celebration"/> After the war the process began of transforming into Bath Academy of Art-based mainly at [[Corsham Court]], [[Corsham]], and with an initial emphasis on training teachers of art.<ref name="saatchi"/> The nascent City of Bath Training College was first based in another house at Sydney Place before its move to [[Newton Park]], meaning that by 1947 (along with [[Bath College of Domestic Science]] then still at Brougham Hayes) all the major components of the future [[Bath Spa University]] were now in existence.
The 1983/4 prospectus contained a short history stating that from 1946 the Academy ran two courses at Corsham, one for teacher training and the other a National Diploma in Design with a small intake, with interaction between the two being seen as a particular asset. The Robbins report of 1963 led to more standardised teacher training provision, and the Academy's course was phased out by 1968. The introduction of Art Foundation courses from 1963 onwards led the Academy to begin such a course, based at the Sydney Place site which had been retained for part-time classes for the general public. In 1974 control of the institution passed to the new Avon County Council and from 1 September 1983 the Academy became part of Bath College of Higher Education.
In 1985/6 the Art and Design courses, now of bachelor's degree status, began the process of moving from Corsham to newly converted premises at Sion Hill, Bath, largely vacated by the switch of Home Economics and related courses to new premises at Newton Park.
[[File:Herman Miller factory, Locksbrook, Bath, 2011.jpg|thumb|upright=1.5|The former Herman Miller factory on the River Avon in Bath becoming the main location for the school in academic year 2019/20]] In 2016 [[Bath Spa University]] purchased the former [[Herman Miller (manufacturer)|Herman Miller]] factory on [[Locksbrook Road, on the River Avon in the west of the City of Bath]], a 1970s listed building designed by [[Farrell & Grimshaw]], to become the main home for an expanded and consolidated Bath School of Art and Design. The School and its courses are to be based across just two buildings, Sion Hill and at Locksbrook Road, rather than up to seven.<ref name=bathchron-20170803>{{cite news |url=http://www.bathchronicle.co.uk/news/bath-news/bath-spa-university-eyes-revamp-264743 |title=Bath Spa University eyes revamp of former Herman Miller site for new school of art and design |last=Crawley |first=James |newspaper=Bath Chronicle |date=3 August 2017 |accessdate=6 August 2017}}</ref><ref name=NHLE-chapels>{{NHLE |num=1415261 |desc=The Herman Miller Factory |grade=II}}</ref>
==Curriculum== Courses at the School include Graphic Communication, Creative Art, Fine Art, Digital Design, Fashion and Textile Design, Ceramics and MA Design (Interaction Design, Ceramics, Brand Development or Textiles), Master of Fine Art.
The School prides itself on the teaching of traditional techniques, while embracing new technologies, and encouraging co-creation across disciplines. The new facilities planned from academic year 2019-20 include spaces specifically to encourage such inter-disciplinary creation.
==Personalities== Visiting artists and tutors have included [[Kenneth Armitage]], [[William Scott (artist)|William Scott]], [[Terry Frost]],<ref name="saatchi"/> [[Peter Lanyon]], [[Sir Herbert Read]], [[Adrian Heath (painter)|Adrian Heath]], [[Bernard Meadows]], [[Howard Hodgkin]],<ref name="saatchi"/> [[Anthony Fry (artist)|Anthony Fry]], [[Martin Froy]], John Colbeck, John Furnival, [[Gillian Ayres]], Peter Potworowski, [[Claes Oldenburg]],<ref name="saatchi"/> James Greaves, [[Peter Kinley]], James Tower, [[John Hoskin]], [[Mark Lancaster (artist)|Mark Lancaster]], [[Michael Craig-Martin]],<ref name="saatchi"/> [[John Ernest]],<ref name="saatchi"/> [[Anthony Hill (artist)|Anthony Hill]], [[Richard Hamilton (artist)|Richard Hamilton]], Roger Clarke,<ref name="saatchi"/> [[Jim Dine]],<ref name="saatchi"/> [[Tom Phillips (artist)|Tom Phillips]], [[Jeremy Gardiner]] and [[Morton Feldman]].
== Notable alumni == <!-- Please list alphabetically by surname --> * [[Paul Bird (artist)|Paul Bird]], artist and teacher<ref name="BuckmanVol1">{{cite book|author=David Buckman|publisher=Art Dictionaries Ltd|year=1998|title=Artists in Britain Since 1945 Vol 1, A to L |ISBN=0 95326 095 X}}</ref> * [[Roger Deakins]], cinematographer<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005683/] Internet Movie Database. Retrieved 18 November 2010</ref> * [[Laura Ford]], artist<ref>[http://www.artnet.com/artist/6352/laura-ford.html] ArtNet Retrieved 18 November 2010</ref> * [[William Harbutt]], artist<ref>[http://www.victoriagal.org.uk/collections/people_william_harbutt.aspx] Victoria Art Gallery. Retrieved 18 November 2010</ref> * [[Salima Hashmi]], artist<ref>[[Salima Hashmi]]</ref> * [[John Hitchens]], artist<ref>[[John Hitchens]]</ref> * [[Howard Hodgkin]], artist<ref>[http://www.victoriagal.org.uk/exhibitions/past_exhibitions/exhibitions_2007/howard_hodgkin_prints.aspx] Victoria Art Gallery Retrieved 18 November 2010</ref> * [[Donald Locke]], artist<ref>[http://www.iniva.org/library/digital_archive/people/l/locke_donald] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161024024625/http://www.iniva.org/library/digital_archive/people/l/locke_donald |date=24 October 2016 }} Iniva website. Retrieved 23 October 2016</ref> * [[Leila Locke]], artist<ref name="Earl1992">Claudette Earl, ''Leila Elizabeth Locke - an appreciation'', Chronicle Family Magazine, April 19, 1992.</ref> * [[John O'Neill (video game designer)|John O'Neill]], video game designer<ref>Forman, Tracie. "Inside Gaming – John O'Neill: The Dali of Computer Gaming." ''[[Electronic Games]]''. Vol.2, No.13. Pp.64–65. July 1984. ISSN 0730-6687.</ref> * [[Edward Piper]], painter<ref>[http://www.tate.org.uk/servlet/ArtistWorks?cgroupid=999999961&artistid=1773&page=1] Tate Gallery. Retrieved 18 November 2010</ref> * [[Peter Randall-Page]], artist<ref>[http://www.tate.org.uk/servlet/ArtistWorks?cgroupid=999999961&artistid=2326&page=1] Tate Collection. Retrieved 18 November 2010</ref> * [[Axel Scheffler]], illustrator<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2006/nov/26/books.booksnews] The Observer Retrieved 18 November 2010</ref> * [[Judith Trim]]<ref name="cooper">{{Cite news|first= Emmanuel| last= Cooper |title= Judy Trim |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/judy-trim-728769.html |newspaper=The Independent |date= 25 January 2001 |accessdate= 14 October 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101003131930/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/judy-trim-728769.html| archivedate= 3 October 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://artdesign.bathspa.ac.uk/ Bath School of Art and Design Website] * [http://www.baacorsham.co.uk/ Information and links for past students/staff at Bath Academy of Art/Corsham Court: including images and reunions]

revision.text:
{{Other uses}} {{Redirect|The Library (journal)||The Library (disambiguation){{!}}The Library}} {{more citations needed|date=May 2017}} Founded in 1892, '''The Bibliographical Society''' is the senior [[learned society]] dealing with the study of the [[book]] and its [[History of books|history]] in the United Kingdom.
The Society holds a monthly lecture between October and May, usually on the third Tuesday of the month at [[University College London]].
The first fifty years of the Bibliographical Society were documented in the book ''The Bibliographical Society, 1892–1942: Studies in Retrospect''.<ref>''The Bibliographical Society, 1892–1942: Studies in Retrospect'' (London, 1949).</ref> ''The Book Encompassed'', a volume of essays marking the Society's centenary was published in 1992.<ref>Peter Davison, ed., ''The Book Encompassed: Studies in Twentieth-century Bibliography'' (Cambridge, 1992) {{ISBN|978-0-521-41878-2}}.</ref>
==Objectives== The objectives of the Society are:
* to promote and encourage study and research in the fields of: ** historical, analytical, descriptive and textual [[bibliography]] ** the [[history of printing]], [[publishing]], [[bookselling]], [[bookbinding]] and [[Book collecting|collecting]] * to hold [[meetings]] at which papers are read and discussed * to print and publish a [[Academic journal|journal]] (''The Library'') and books concerned with bibliography * to maintain a bibliographical [[library]] * from time to time to award a [[medal]] for services to bibliography * to support bibliographical research by awarding [[Grant (money)|grants and bursaries]]
==Library and archives== The Society's library was housed at [[Worshipful Company of Stationers and Newspaper Makers|Stationers' Hall]] in the [[City of London]] but moved to [[Senate House (University of London)|Senate House]] in January 2007 where it is now available alongside the resources of the [[Senate House Libraries]].
The Society's [[archive]] is housed at the [[Bodleian Library]] and may be used by scholars and members of the Society.
==Publications== The Society has published a journal since 1893, originally entitled ''Transactions of the Bibliographical Society''. In 1920 it took over publication of ''The Library'' (issued since 1889) and adopted that as the main title of the ''Transactions''. (''The Library'' was founded in 1889 by [[John Young Walker MacAlister]].<ref>{{cite journal|title=MacAlister, John Y. W.|journal=Who's Who|year=1916|pages= 1389|url=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.b3453981;view=1up;seq=1429}}</ref>) The different series of the ''Transactions'' and ''The Library'' are:
*''Transactions of the Bibliographical Society'', vol. 1–15 (1893–1919) *''The Library'', vol. 1–10 (1889–1898) *''The Library'', Second/New series, vol. 1–10 (1900–1910) *''The Library'', Third series, vol. 1–10 (1910–1919) *''The Library'', Fourth series, vol. 1–26 (1920–1946) *''The Library'', Fifth series, vol. 1–33 (1946–1978) *''The Library'', Sixth series, vol. 1–21 (1979–1999) *''The Library'', Seventh series, vol. 1– (2000– )
''The Library'' ({{ISSN|0024-2160}}; {{ISSN search link|1744-8581}}) is a quarterly journal and is issued free to members who also receive a copy of all books published by the Society.
==Gold medal== The Society occasionally awards a [[gold]] medal for distinguished services to bibliography to individuals who have made an outstanding contribution to the development of the subject and the furtherance of the Society's aims.
{| class="wikitable sortable collapsible" |+ Bibliographical Society Gold Medallists<ref>{{cite web |title=Gold Medalists |publisher=Bibliographical Society |url=http://bibsoc.org.uk/content/gold-medalists |accessdate=29 April 2016}}</ref> |- ! Year ! Recipient |- | 1929 | [[Wilberforce Eames|Eames, Wilberforce]] |- | 1929 | [[:de:Konrad Haebler|Haebler, Konrad]] |- | 1929 | [[M. R. James|James, Montague Rhodes]] |- | 1929 | [[Ronald Brunlees McKerrow|McKerrow, Ronald Brunlees]] |- | 1929 | [[Alfred W. Pollard|Pollard, Alfred W.]] |- | 1932 | [[Falconer Madan|Madan, Falconer]] |- | 1935 | [[Frederic G. Kenyon|Kenyon, Frederic G.]] |- | 1935 | [[Walter Wilson Greg|Greg, Walter Wilson]] |- | 1948 | [[Stanley Morison|Morison, Stanley]] |- | 1948 | [[Strickland Gibson|Gibson, Strickland]] |- | 1951 | [[Frederic Sutherland Ferguson|Ferguson, Frederic Sutherland]] |- | 1951 | [[Victor Scholderer|Scholderer, Victor]] |- | 1956 | [[Maria Elizabeth Kronenberg|Kronenberg, Maria Elizabeth]] |- | 1956 | [[Alfred Forbes Johnson|Johnson, Alfred Forbes]] |- | 1957 | [[Lawrence C. Wroth|Wroth, Lawrence C.]] |- | 1960 | [[Elias Avery Lowe|Lowe, Elias Avery]] |- | 1960 | [[J. Basil Oldham|Oldham, J. Basil]] |- | 1965 | [[William Alexander Jackson|Jackson, William Alexander]] |- | 1969 | [[Fredson Bowers|Bowers, Fredson]] |- | 1969 | [[Graham Pollard|Pollard, Graham]] |- | 1975 | [[John Carter (author)|Carter, John]] |- | 1975 | [[Neil Ripley Ker|Ker, Neil Ripley]] |- | 1978 | [[Howard M. Nixon|Nixon, Howard M.]] |- | 1982 | [[:de:Bernhard Bischoff|Bischoff, Bernhard]] |- | 1982 | [[Geoffrey Keynes|Keynes, Geoffrey]] |- | 1984 | [[David Foxon|Foxon, David]] |- | 1986 | [[Paul Oskar Kristeller|Kristeller, Paul Oskar]] |- | 1988 | [[Katharine Pantzer|Pantzer, Katharine]] |- | 1990 | [[Donald Francis McKenzie|McKenzie, Donald Francis]] |- | 1992 | [[Anthony R. A. Hobson|Hobson, Anthony R. A.]] |- | 1994 | [[Henri-Jean Martin|Martin, Henri-Jean]] |- | 1997 | [[Robin Alston|Alston, Robin]] |- | 1999 | [[Nicolas Barker|Barker, Nicolas]] |- | 1999 | [[Bernhard Fabian|Fabian, Bernhard]] |- | 2001 | [[Andrew G. Watson|Watson, Andrew G.]] |- | 2003 | [[Peter Hobley Davison|Davison, Peter Hobley]] |- | 2005 | [[David McKitterick|McKitterick, David]] |- | 2007 | [[Dennis Rhodes|Rhodes, Dennis]] |- | 2009 | [[Lotte Hellinga|Hellinga, Lotte]] |- | 2011 | [[Paul Needham (librarian)|Needham, Paul]] |- | 2013 | [[Mirjam Foot|Foot, Mirjam]] |- | 2015 | [[G. Thomas Tanselle|Tanselle, G. Thomas]] |}
==See also== * [[Bibliographical Society of America]] * Sir [[Frank Francis]] and [[Julian Roberts]], former joint secretaries of the Society * [[Society for the History of Authorship, Reading and Publishing]] * [[Books in the United Kingdom]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.bibsoc.org.uk/ Bibliographical Society official website] * {{citation |title=Transactions of the Bibliographical Society, 1893- |publisher=Bibliographical Society |location=London |year= |url=http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/000545110 }} (HathiTrust)

{{more citations needed|date=May 2012}} {{Infobox NRHP | name =Cheekwood | nrhp_type = | image = WTN_PeepHoles_082.JPG | caption = Cheekwood Mansion | location= 1200 Forest Park Dr., [[Nashville, Tennessee]] | coordinates = {{coord|36|5|12|N|86|52|26|W|display=inline,title}} | locmapin = Tennessee#USA | built = 1929 | architect = [[Bryant Fleming]]; et al. | architecture = Colonial Revival | added = August 23, 2000 | area = {{convert|7|acre}} | governing_body = Private | refnum = 00000993<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|2009a}}</ref> }} '''Cheekwood''' is a privately funded {{convert|55|acre|ha|adj=on}} estate on the western edge of [[Nashville, Tennessee]] that houses the '''Cheekwood Botanical Garden and Museum of Art'''. Formerly the residence of Nashville's Cheek family, the {{convert|30000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} [[Georgian architecture|Georgian]]-style mansion was opened as a museum in 1960.
== History == Christopher Cheek founded a wholesale [[grocery]] business in Nashville in the 1880s. His son, Leslie Cheek, joined him as a partner, and by 1915 was president of the family-owned company. Leslie's wife, Mabel Wood, was a member of a prominent [[Clarksville, Tennessee]], family. Meanwhile, [[Joel Owsley Cheek]], Leslie's cousin, had developed an acclaimed blend of [[coffee]] that was marketed through Nashville's finest hotel, the [[Maxwell House Hotel]]. Cheek's extended family, including Leslie and Mabel Cheek, were investors. In 1928, the [[Postum]] Cereals Company (now [[General Foods]]) purchased [[Maxwell House]]'s parent company, Cheek-Neal Coffee, for more than $40 million.<ref name=AboutCheekwoodHistory>{{cite web |url=http://www.cheekwood.org/About.aspx |title=History of Cheekwood |publisher=Cheekwood Botanical Gardens and Museum of Art |accessdate=December 8, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131208011001/http://www.cheekwood.org/About.aspx# |archive-date=2013-12-08 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
After the sale of the family business, Leslie Cheek bought {{convert|100|acre|ha}} of woodland in West Nashville for a country estate. He hired [[New York City|New York]] residential and landscape architect [[Bryant Fleming]] to design the house and gardens, and gave him full control over every detail of the project, including interior furnishings. The resulting [[limestone]] mansion and extensive formal gardens were completed in 1932. The estate design was inspired by the grand [[England|English]] manors of the 18th century.<ref name=AboutCheekwoodHistory/>
Leslie Cheek died just two years after moving into the mansion. Mabel Cheek and their daughter, Huldah Cheek Sharp, lived at Cheekwood until the 1950s, when Huldah Sharp and her husband offered the property as a site for a botanical garden and art museum. The Exchange Club of Nashville, the Horticultural Society of Middle Tennessee and other civic groups led the redevelopment of the property aided by funds raised from the sale of the former building of the defunct Nashville Museum of Art. The new Cheekwood museum opened in 1960.<ref name=AboutCheekwoodHistory/>
== Art museum == Cheekwood's art collection was founded in 1959 upon the holdings of the former [[Nashville Museum of Art]] and is accredited by the [[American Alliance of Museums]]. The core holdings include broad collections of American art; American and British decorative arts; contemporary art, especially outdoor sculpture acquired for the Woodland Sculpture Trail.
Cheekwood's American art collection includes 600 paintings and 5,000 prints, drawings and photographs. The collection, assembled in the 1980s and early 1990s through a multimillion-dollar bequest, spans the history of American art. Its strength centers on [[The Eight (Nyolcak)|The Eight]]. Other strengths include the world's largest collection of sculptures of [[William Edmondson]], photographs by [[Louise Dahl-Wolfe]], and a vast variety of post-[[Second World War]] prints. Recently, the Museum has pursued a consciously focused acquisition process, having added paintings by James Hamilton, [[William Bradford (painter)|William Bradford]], and new contemporary sculpture for the Trail.
The core holdings of the decorative arts collection include the third-largest [[Worcester]] porcelain in the [[United States]], and a 650-piece silver collection, spanning the 18th-20th centuries.
The Cheek Mansion is itself considered part of the collection. A year-long renovation, completed in June 2017, restored much of the original building, which revealed authentic features (wood and marble floors that had been carpeted), and conserved historical architectural motifs, such as the illusionist murals that line the main corridor.
The Contemporary Art collection, housed in the galleries created out of the estate's original garage and stables, is small but of high quality, including paintings by [[Larry Rivers]], [[Andy Warhol]], [[Robert Ryman]], [[Red Grooms]], and [[Marylyn Dintenfass]]. Additionally, seven small galleries were created in the old horse stable stalls to enable Cheekwood to display installation art.
The Carrell Woodland Sculpture Trail, a collection of fifteen sculptures by international artists, extends the contemporary art collection into nature, focusing on a kind of intimate, outdoor art not commonly found in American museums.
== Botanical garden == [[File:Polemonium reptans 2009.jpg|thumb|250px|[[Creeping Jacob's Ladder]] (''Polemonium reptans'') at Cheekwood Botanical Garden]] Extending across the grounds from the Museum of Art, the Botanical Garden encompasses the entire {{convert|55|acre|ha|adj=on}} site with an emphasis on display, education, and study. The plant collections include [[Buxus|boxwood]], [[conifer]], [[crape myrtle]], [[daffodil]], [[daylily]], [[dogwood]], [[fern]], [[herb]], [[holly]], [[hosta]], [[hydrangea]], [[Japanese maple]], [[magnolia]], Southeastern US natives, [[redbud]], and [[trillium]].
== Other attractions == In addition to the Museum and the Botanical Garden, Cheekwood operates a nick-nack shop, and a restaurant called the Pineapple Room which overlooks the west lawn.
== See also == * [[List of botanical gardens and arboretums in the United States]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category}} *[http://www.cheekwood.org Cheekwood official site]
{{Nashville landmarks}}

{{Infobox company |name=Ciné-Asie |logo= CAC Packshot Banner.jpg |logo_size= 225px |type= [[Non-profit Organization]] |founder= Mi-Jeong Lee |foundation=1996 |location_city= [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]] [[Canada]] |industry= |homepage= [http://www.cineasie.ca/ cineasie.ca]
[http://www.cineasiecreatives.com cineasiecreatives.com] }} '''Ciné-Asie''' (official name: Ciné-Asie Film Institute) is a Montreal-based, [[non-profit]] Film and Media Company that seeks to explore the unique identity of Asian-Canadian media arts and artists. Its mission is to develop and create cinema that empowers people who are marginalized by [[mass media]] and to introduce the Asian cult and genre films to the wider public. Ciné-Asie is involved in many different projects including film contests, [[exhibitions]] and film screenings at the [[Cinémathèque québécoise]]. In 2008, the company [[Ciné-Asie Creatives]] was established under the umbrella of Ciné-Asie. This division of the company is dedicated to the [[international co-production]] of Canadian and Asian films as well as sales and distribution of films between Canada and Asia. Ciné-Asie Creatives is currently developing a co-production [[feature film]] in cooperation with six Asian directors. In addition, Ciné-Asie Creatives acquired the Canadian distribution rights to the Korean films [[Breathless (2009 film)|Breathless]] by [[Yang Ik-june]] and [[My Dear Enemy]] by [[Lee Yoon-ki]]. == History == Founded in 1996 as a registered company, Ciné-Asie started its activities in 1997 with the "Three Korean Master Filmmakers" event in Montreal, Ottawa, Toronto, and Vancouver in collaboration with cinémathèques in Canada and the New York Cultural Center. Between 1998 and 2000 Ciné-Asie hosted monthly Asian and Asian-American film screenings and seminars in partnership with the Cinémathèque Québécoise in Montreal. During this time Ciné-Asie also organized Asian film events at the [[Asia Pacific Foundation of Canada]] and published the bilingual monthly local film newsletter "QuiFaitQuoi" on Asian film and filmmakers from Canada and abroad. In 1999, Ciné-Asie was incorporated and co-organized "Chinese Cinema, 1933-49" together with [[Concordia University (Montreal)|Concordia University]] as part of the Film Society of Lincoln. That same year Ciné Asie organized the "Amérasia International Film and Video Festival" in Montreal and started to host monthly social events for the Asian Film and Video Art Society, a support group of Asian-Canadian artists. After a six-year break Ciné-Asie resumed its work by programming and coordinating Asian-Canadian film screenings at the Asian Heritage Festival for Access-Asie, a non-profit organization in Montreal. In addition, Ciné-Asie intensified its collaboration with the Cinémathèque Québécoise in Montreal by organizing a retrospective of Korean Films in 2006 and of director [[Hong Sang-soo]]'s films in 2007. In 2008 Ciné-Asie also resumed its monthly Asian-Canadian film screenings presented at the Cinémathèque Québécois. == Ciné-Asie Projects == === Film Screenings=== Ciné-Asie organizes regular film screenings of Asian and Asian-Canadian films at the Cinémathèque Québécoise. '''List of Screenings:''' *'''January 2011 - The Man from Nowhere'''http://www.cineasiecreatives.com/nowhere/ The Man From Nowhere His only friend called him 'the man from nowhere' ... Taesik, a former special agent becomes a loner after losing his wife in a miserable accident and lives a bitter life running a pawnshop. He only has a few customers and a friend named Somi, a little girl next door. As Taesik spends more and more time with Somi, he gets attached to her. Then Somi is kidnapped by a gang and as Taesik tries to save her by becoming deeply associated with the gang, his mysterious past is revealed ... *'''July 2009 - L'Empire Du Désir, Films Érotiques Japonais'''{{cite web |url=http://www.cinematheque.qc.ca/affiche/eros_japonais.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-08-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090806004838/http://www.cinematheque.qc.ca/affiche/eros_japonais.html |archivedate=2009-08-06 |df= }} Showcase of erotic films from the genre of pinku eiga ([[Pink film]]) including films from [[Tetsuji Takechi]], [[Kan Mukai]], and [[Noboru Tanaka]] in partnership with [[Fantasia Festival]] *'''May 2009 - [[Irezumi]] – Spirit of Tattoo''' (Sekka Tomurai Zashi) [1982] Director: Yoichi Tokabayashi *'''April 2009 - [[Life on a String (film)|Life on a String]]''' (Bian zou bian chang) [1991] Director: [[Chen Kaige]] Nominated for the [[Golden Palm]] Award at the [[Cannes Film Festival]] and winner of the Golden Tulip Award at the [[Istanbul International Film Festival]] *'''March 2009 - [[Chungking Express]]''' (Chongqing senlin) [1994] Director: [[Wong Kar-wai]] Cinematographer: [[Christopher Doyle]] and [[Wai-keung Lau]] Winner of the 1997 [[Independent Spirit Award]] for Best Foreign film === National Video Portrait Contest === Since 2008, Ciné-Asie hosts an annual Video Portrait Contest.{{cite web |url=http://communities.canada.com/montrealgazette/blogs/thecinefiles/archive/2009/05/20/film-and-video-contest-friday-at-cin-233-math-232-que.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-08-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120710054116/http://communities.canada.com/montrealgazette/blogs/thecinefiles/archive/2009/05/20/film-and-video-contest-friday-at-cin-233-math-232-que.aspx |archivedate=2012-07-10 |df= }} The contest is an event that provides emerging Asian and Canadian visual media artists with an opportunity to show their short films in public. The films are judged by a panel of five jury members from the professional filmmaking and visual media arts industry. In 2009, the participating jury members were: [[Yung Chang]], director of [[Up the Yangtze]] (2007); Germaine Ying Gee Wong, producer of Up the Yangtze (2007); Malcolm Guy, producer, director, and president of Productions Multi-Monde; Liz Ferguson, film critic for the [[Montreal Gazette]]; and François Laurent, director and president of the Cinema Students Association (CSA) of Concordia University. The winning short films of Ciné-Asie's second National Portrait Contest in 2009 were: Nguyen-Anh Nguyen with Mon nom est Tuan (2008); Jason Karman with State of Yo (2007); Kelly-Anne Riess with A Tall Tale (2009); and Mina Vladimir with Harvest Moon (2009). === Jeon Soo-il retrospective tour === Ciné-Asie, in cooperation with the Cinémathéque Québécoise in Montreal, will show a [[retrospective]] of South Korean director [[Jeon Soo-il]] 's feature films, including his latest film With a Girl of Black Soil (2007). The entire retrospective will be screened from November 2009 until January 2010, starting in Montreal, with stops in Ottawa, Toronto, Vancouver and Los Angeles. == References == == External links == * {{Official website|http://cineasiecreatives.com/}} * [http://www.amerasiafestival.com/ Festival AmerAsia] {{DEFAULTSORT:Cine-Asie}} [[Category:Culture of Montreal]] [[Category:Cinema of Quebec]] [[Category:Organizations based in Montreal]] [[Category:Asian-Canadian cinema]] [[Category:Film organizations in Canada]]

revision.comment: created article as translation from [[:es:Gestor cultural|Spanish Wikipedia]]
revision.text:
A '''cultural manager''' ({{lang-es|'''gestor cultural'''}}) is a person who is motivated by the improvement of [[art]], works independently and professionally with knowledge of the subject, and develops work as a mediator between governmental and/or private cultural institutions with artists from different areas to articulate their work in the market with promotion and national and international dissemination.<ref name=uoc>{{Cite web |url=http://gestiocultural.blogs.uoc.edu/2016/06/28/que-es-un-gestor-cultural-gestion-cultural/ |title=¿Qué es un gestor cultural? |trans-title=What is a Cultural Manager? |publisher=[[Open University of Catalonia]] |language=Spanish |date=28 June 2016 |access-date=18 April 2018}}</ref>
The cultural manager works by looking for specific measures of success, always intending to improve the level of culture, seeking active cohesion between society, the governmental sector, the private sector, and the artists. The work of culture management poses learning challenges in diverse areas such as the administration of economic resources, training, and artistic communication.<ref name=uoc/><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.educaweb.com/profesion/gestor-cultural-334/ |title=Gestor cultural |publisher=Educaweb |language=Spanish |access-date=18 April 2018}}</ref>
Cultural management is a new profession. A person who is dedicated to this work is characterized by having abilities to visualize and interpret talent, knowing how to establish a dialogue with artists to link them to cultural projects to develop.<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2hHxeCA_ecYC&pg=PA13 |title=Gestión cultural: Entre conceptos lejanos y realidades cercanas |trans-title=Cultural Management: Between Distant Concepts and Nearby Realities |chapter=Acercando realidades a través de la gestión cultural |trans-chapter=Bringing Together Realities Through Cultural Management |first1=Silvia |last1=Aballay |first2=Carla Fernanda |last2=Avendaño Manelli |publisher=Eduvim |isbn=9789871518968 |pages=13-16 |language=Spanish |year=2010 |access-date=18 April 2018 |via=Google Books}}</ref>
Universities that offer degree programs in cultural management include the [[University of Antioquia]],<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.udea.edu.co/wps/portal/udea/web/inicio/institucional/unidades-academicas/facultades/artes/programas-academicos/programas-posgrado/contenido/asmenulateral/maestria-gestion-cultural/ |title=Maestría en Gestión Cultural |trans-title=Master's in Cultural Management |publisher=[[University of Antioquia]] |language=Spanish |access-date=18 April 2018}}</ref> the [[Latin American Social Sciences Institute]],<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://en.unesco.org/creativity/sites/creativity/files/training%20in%20cultural%20management_es.pdf |title=Formación en gestión cultural y políticas culturales |trans-title=Training in Cultural Management and Cultural Policies |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |pages=53-54 |language=Spanish |year=2005 |access-date=18 April 2018}}</ref> the [[University of Chile]],<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.uchile.cl/publicaciones/92958/revista-de-gestion-cultural |title=Revista de Gestión Cultural |trans-title=Journal of Cultural Management |publisher=[[University of Chile]] |language=Spanish |access-date=18 April 2018}}</ref> the [[University of Córdoba (Spain)]],<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.uco.es/filosofiayletras/ggestioncultural/index.html |title=Grado de Gestión Cultural |trans-title=Degree in Cultural Management |publisher=[[University of Córdoba (Spain)|University of Córdoba]] |language=Spanish |access-date=18 April 2018}}</ref> the [[National University of Colombia]],<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://agenciadenoticias.unal.edu.co/detalle/article/la-un-ofrecera-maestria-en-gestion-cultural.html |title=La U.N. ofrecerá Maestría en Gestión Cultural |trans-title=The U.N. Will Offer a Master's in Cultural Management |publisher=[[National University of Colombia]] |location=Manizales |language=Spanish |date=27 February 2018 |access-date=18 April 2018}}</ref> the [[University of Barcelona]],<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.ub.edu/web/ub/es/estudis/oferta_formativa/master_universitari/fitxa/G/M0304/index.html |title=Máster de Gestión Cultural |trans-title=Master's of Cultural Management |publisher=[[University of Barcelona]] |language=Spanish |access-date=18 April 2018}}</ref> and the [[University of Piura]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://udep.edu.pe/humanidades/mgc/ |title=Gestión Cultural |publisher=[[University of Piura]] |language=Spanish |access-date=18 April 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Arts occupations]] [[Category:Culture]]
